contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Benjamin Paul Akers | image = [[File:01-Akers Benjamin Paul-03.jpg|thumb|Photo portrait of Paul Akers[[File:01-Akers Benjamin Paul Signature.jpg|thumb|Signature of Paul Akers]]]] | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date |1825|7|10|}} | birth_place = [[Westbrook, Maine]] | death_date = {{Death date and age |1861|5|21|1825|7|10|}} | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[Sculpture]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = [[Samuel Appleton]] and [[John Neal]] | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = Commemorative Silver Medal in 1854 }} '''Benjamin Paul Akers''' (July 10, 1825 – May 21, 1861) was an American [[sculpture|sculptor]], from [[Maine]]. ==Early life== Born in [[Saccarappa, Maine]] in 1825, into a large and indigent family of rural Maine. When his father, Deacon Akers, moved the family from Saccarappa to [[Salmon Falls]]{{dn|date=March 2013}} on the [[Saco River]], he started a wood-turning mill. For six years as a young man he worked in his father's "wood turning" mill. There he invented beautiful patterns and "turned" toys. His brother, Charles "Carl" Akers was also a sculptor and crayon portrait artist. He wrote articles on art for the [[Atlantic Monthly]] and also "The Crayon" a short-lived, New York art magazine in the mid-19th century.<ref>[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/benjamin-paul-akers-letter-collection-5644 Archives of American Art]</ref> He spent the winter of 1849 in Boston learning the art of plaster casting with the sculptor, [[Joseph Carew]]. In 1850 he opened a studio in Portland, Maine. He received a "Commemorative Silver Medal" in the 1854 Exhibition and Fair of the Maine Charitable Mechanic Association. He moved to [[Boston]] in 1849 where he was an apprentice. The award was for his bas relief called "Peace". <ref>{{cite journal|last=Usher|first=Leila Woodman|title=Benjamin Paul Akers|journal=New England magazine: an illustrated monthly|year=1895|volume=11|pages=461–468}}</ref> In 1855, at age 30, he went to [[Rome, Italy]] where he worked for several years.<ref>[http://www.mainememory.net/artifact/14682 Maine Memory]</ref> ==Career== [[File:01-Akers Paul, the Pearl Diver.jpg|thumb|Sculpture called The Pearl Diver]] Among his works are busts of [[Edward Everett]] and [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]], a head of [[John Milton]] and ''[[The Pearl Diver]]'', on display at the [[Portland Museum of Art]] in [[Portland, Maine]]. [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]] described ''Dead Pearl Diver'' as an important work of the protagonist, Kenyon, in his novel ''[[The Marble Faun]]'', acknowledging his debt to Akers in the introduction. ==Marriage and children== In 1858 he met [[Elizabeth Anne Chase Akers Allen]] a young mother, journalist and poet. They married in August of 1860. Their only child, Gertrude Rothermel died in infancy. He died in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on May 21, 1861 from [[tuberculosis]].<ref>[http://chestofbooks.com/reference/American-Cyclopaedia-V1/Benjamin-Paul-Akers.html Chest of Books]</ref> He is buried in [[Evergreen Cemetery (Portland, Maine)]].<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Akers&GSiman=1&GSst=23&GRid=63823565& Find-A-Grave]</ref> ==Museums and public art galleries worldwide== * [[Boston Museum of Fine Art]], Boston, Massachusetts * [[Harvard University Art Museums]], Massachusetts * [[Portland Museum of Art]], Maine <ref>[http://www.artcyclopedia.com/artists/akers_benjamin_paul.html Art Encyclopedia]</ref> ==Books About Benjamin Paul Akers== * Akers, Benjamin Paul by [[Thomas William Herrigshaw]] * Akers, Benjamin Paul, article in [[National Cyclopedia of American Biography]], Vol. 6 * Akers, Benjamin Paul, book by [[George C.
